questions.question: The Minister has …………………… to come.
questions.description: Before an infinitive, we use agree, not accept.

questions.question: In most countries you have to be …………………….. 18 to drive a car.
questions.description: We use over to talk about ages and speeds.

questions.question: The boys swam ……………………….. the river.
questions.description: We usually prefer across to talk about movement in water.

questions.question: ……………………….. scientists, smoking can cause cancer.
questions.description: According to scientists means ‘if what scientists say is true’.

questions.question: The boy jumped ……………………….. the wall.
questions.description: Over can mean on or to the other side of something high.

questions.question: I am interested ……………………….. to fly.
questions.description: The adjective ‘interested’ is usually followed by ‘in + noun/ ing form’.

questions.question: I am anxious for my daughter ……………………….. a good job.
questions.description: Anxious to get means eager to get.

questions.question: My ………………………. jobs were very stressful.
questions.description: The adjectives first, second, next and last usually go before one, two, three etc.

questions.question: My husband is six years ……………………….. than me.
questions.description: The adjectives elder and eldest can only be used before a noun. After a verb we use other words like older and oldest. Here we use ‘elder’ because we need a comparative form before ‘than’.

questions.question: I don’t remember him ………………………
questions.description: Well is an adverb good is an adjective. We need an adverb to modify a verb.

questions.question: I could read only the ...................................... chapters of the book.
questions.description: The adjectives first, second, next and last usually go before one, two, three etc.

questions.question: He has few reasons for staying, ..................................?
questions.description: Clauses with little and few are followed by affirmative question tags.
